lead_paragraph: We come together in crowds so regularly, as strangers finding our ways — consider how immigrants do this more often and better than anyone, wanting to blend, be made invisible graciously. The lyrical passages in Meena Alexander’s eloquent final book track her lifetime of far-flung journeys, crisscrossing the globe, from her own childhood in Kerala, India, to Venice and Manhattan. New York City presides as destination of brave generations, who quickly learn its neighborhoods and alleyways, the idiosyncrasies of acceptance and the richest identity of mingling. Selected by Naomi Shihab Nye
